how to cite github repo in bibtext

thoughts.content:
To cite a GitHub repository in BibTeX, use entry types like `@misc` or `@software`. Key fields include author, title, year, version, URL, commit, and accessed date. Here's an example format:

```
@misc{author2023repo,
  author = {Author Name},
  title = {Repository Title},
  year = {2023},
  version = {v1.0},
  url = {https://github.com/repo},
  accessdate = {2023-04-09},
  commit = {commit-hash}
}
```

Let me know if you'd need further explanation!

parts:
Here’s a practical way to cite a GitHub repository in **BibTeX** (classic `.bib` files) and in **Bib LaTeX** (`biblatex`), keeping everything comment-free as you requested.

---

## 1. Plain BibTeX (`natbib`, `plain`, etc.)

```bibtex
@misc{repo-key,
  author       = {GitHubUsername},
  title        = {Project Name: Short Description},
  howpublished = {\url{https://github.com/GitHubUsername/RepoName}},
  note         = {Commit abcdefg, accessed 2025-05-11},
  year         = {2025}
}
```

**Key points**

- `author` – put the main maintainer’s real name if available; otherwise use the GitHub handle.  
- `title` – repo name plus a succinct description.  
- `howpublished` – wrap the URL in `\url{}` (needs `\usepackage{url}` or loaded by most citation styles).  
- `note` – record the exact commit hash (or a release tag) and the access date so the reference is frozen in time.  
- `year` – the year of the cited version (often the current year).

---

## 2. Bib LaTeX (preferred for software)

With `\usepackage{biblatex}` you can use the dedicated `@software` entry type:

```bibtex
@software{repo-key,
  author    = {GitHubUsername},
  title     = {Project Name: Short Description},
  version   = {v1.2.3},
  url       = {https://github.com/GitHubUsername/RepoName},
  date      = {2025-05-11},
  note      = {Commit abcdefg},
  urldate   = {2025-05-11}
}
```

If the repository has a DOI minted by Zenodo or similar, add:

```bibtex
  doi       = {10.5281/zenodo.1234567},
```

---

## 3. Choosing good citation details

| Field            | What to fill with                                                |
|------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **author**       | Individual(s) or organization maintaining the repo               |
| **title**        | Formal project name + subtitle/description                       |
| **version**      | Tagged release (`v1.4.0`) or short commit hash                   |
| **year / date**  | Release date or date you cloned/accessed it                      |
| **url**          | Canonical HTTPS link to the repo or release permalink            |
| **note**         | “Commit abc1234” or “Release v1.4.0” for permanence              |
| **doi** (opt.)   | DOI if the code is archived (e.g., Zenodo)                       |

---

## 4. Quick checklist before you add it

1. **Freeze a version** – cite a tagged release or commit, not the moving default branch.  
2. **Include the access date** – essential for material that can change.  
3. **Prefer a DOI** – archiving via Zenodo gives you a stable, citable record.  
4. **Stay consistent** – whatever fields you use, follow the same pattern for every software reference in your bibliography.

That’s it—drop one of the snippets into your `.bib` file and cite it with `\cite{repo-key}` (or the appropriate Bib LaTeX command).
what is the name of the infinite spectrum of dimensions D_q for a fractal?

That family is usually called the **generalized (or Rényi) dimensions** of the set.  For each real parameter \(q\), the generalized dimension  

\[
D_q=\frac{1}{q-1}\,\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\,
      \frac{\log\!\bigl(\sum_i p_i^{\,q}\bigr)}
           {\log \varepsilon},
\]

(where the \(p_i\) are the measures of the boxes of size \(\varepsilon\)) captures how the measure redistributes across scales.  Taken together for all \(q\in\mathbb{R}\), the collection \(\{D_q\}_{q\in\mathbb{R}}\) is often referred to as **the infinite spectrum of generalized (Rényi) dimensions** in multifractal analysis.  Special cases include the capacity dimension \(D_0\), the information dimension \(D_1\), and the correlation dimension \(D_2\).
are these exactly the same if p is uniform

thoughts.content: The user asks if the dimensions are the same if p is uniform. In the case of a uniform measure, p_i is equidistributed. This leads to the calculation where the sum of p_i^q simplifies to N * (1/N)^q = N^(1-q), and the box-counting dimension equivalent to D_q becomes independent of q. For q=1, the limit also confirms the result. So, yes, the dimensions coincide for uniform measures. The behavior for q → ∞ might also be worth mentioning.

parts:
Yes.  
If the probability weights are uniform across the \(N(\varepsilon)\) occupied boxes—so every box gets \(p_i = 1/N(\varepsilon)\)—then

\[
\sum_i p_i^{\,q}=N(\varepsilon)\left(\tfrac1{N(\varepsilon)}\right)^{q}=N(\varepsilon)^{\,1-q}.
\]

Insert this in the definition for \(q\neq 1\):

\[
D_q =\frac{1}{q-1}\,
       \frac{\log N(\varepsilon)^{\,1-q}}{\log\varepsilon}
     =\frac{1-q}{q-1}\,
       \frac{\log N(\varepsilon)}{\log\varepsilon}
     =\frac{\log N(\varepsilon)}{\log(1/\varepsilon)}.
\]

The right-hand expression is exactly the usual box-counting (capacity) dimension \(D_0\), so \(D_q=D_0\) for every \(q\neq1\).

For \(q=1\) you take the limit,

\[
D_1=\lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\frac{\sum_i p_i\log p_i}{\log\varepsilon}
    =\lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\frac{-\log N(\varepsilon)}{\log(1/\varepsilon)}
    =\frac{\log N(\varepsilon)}{\log(1/\varepsilon)},
\]

which is the same value again. Hence, when the measure is uniform (the set is not multifractal), the entire spectrum collapses to a single number: every generalized (Rényi) dimension equals the box-counting dimension.

who should I cite for renyi entropy in this passage, sepcifically its use as a fractal dimension

\textit{Fractal Dimension}: Dissipative chaotic dynamical systems tend to settle to attractors which integrate to zero phase space volume but cannot be represented as an integer-dimensional manifold. These are called fractal attractors, and they are characterized by their fractal dimension. Fractal dimension approximately represents the number of degrees of freedom in a given set, and there are several relevant definitions for fractal dimension. We focus on specific cases of Rényi entropy, defined as

\[
D_\alpha = \frac{1}{1-\alpha} \lim_{\varepsilon\to 0} \frac{\log \sum_{i} p_i^\alpha}{\log \varepsilon},
\]

\noindent where $p_i$ is the total probability of the $i$-th box in a uniform partition of phase space with some resolution $\varepsilon$. $D_0$ is the \textit{box-counting dimension}, $D_1$ is the \textit{information dimension}, and $D_2$ is the \textit{correlation dimension}. These only differ when the distribution of density on the attractor is non-uniform.

thoughts.summary: Citing for Rényi entropy and fractal dimensions
thoughts.content: For the user's request on citing Rényi entropy used for fractal dimensions, we could reference Alfred Rényi, who introduced generalized entropy in 1961. Regarding fractal dimensions, Thomas and Rényi’s work could be included, along with the 1983 papers by Grassberger and Procaccia on correlation dimensions (D2), and Hentschel and Procaccia’s work on generalized dimensions and multifractals. Specifically, Grassberger's "Generalized dimensions of strange attractors" and Hentschel & Procaccia’s paper are key references.

thoughts.summary: Citing Rényi entropy and fractal dimensions
thoughts.content: To cite Rényi entropy and its application to fractal dimensions, I recommend referencing Alfred Rényi (1961) for entropy, Hentschel & Procaccia (1983) for generalized dimensions and multifractals, and possibly Grassberger (1983) for correlation dimension. While Minkowski (1903) is key for box-counting dimension, Falconer’s "Fractal Geometry" (1990) is another resource for fractal dimension definitions. For added depth, Kaplan & Yorke (1981) and Feder (1988) could also be included, though they might not be essential.

thoughts.content:
For the user's inquiry on Rényi entropy and fractal dimensions, citations to consider include: 

1. Rényi (1961) for entropy definition.
2. Hentschel & Procaccia (1983) for generalized dimensions and fractal dimensions.
3. Grassberger (1983) for correlation dimension, along with Grassberger & Procaccia (1983) on strange attractors.
4. Falconer’s "Fractal Geometry" (1990) for concepts of fractal dimensions.
5. Optionally, Beck & Schlögl (1987) on dynamical systems and multifractals.

We aim to gather at least 10 high-quality citations, keeping them concise but informative based on the context.

parts:
Below is a compact set of well-established sources that are routinely cited when Rényi entropy is used to define the spectrum of fractal (generalized) dimensions.  In most papers people combine several of them in a single parenthetical citation—e.g. “(Rényi 1961; Hentschel & Procaccia 1983; Grassberger 1983).”

## 1  Original introduction of Rényi entropy  

| Reference | Why it matters |
|-----------|---------------|
|Alfréd Rényi, “**On Measures of Entropy and Information**,” _Proc. 4th Berkeley Symp._ (1961) 547–561 citeturn0search0|First definition of the one-parameter family of entropies that now bears his name.|

## 2  Linking Rényi entropy to fractal/generalized dimensions  

| Reference | Contribution |
|-----------|--------------|
|H. G. E. Hentschel & I. Procaccia, “**The infinite number of generalized dimensions of fractals and strange attractors**,” _Physica D_ 8 (1983) 435–444 citeturn0search1turn0search8|Introduced the formula \(D_\alpha\) (often written \(D_q\)) via Rényi entropies and showed how each order \(q\) captures different aspects of the invariant measure on an attractor.|
|Peter Grassberger, “**Generalized dimensions of strange attractors**,” _Phys. Lett. A_ 97 (1983) 227–230 citeturn0search2turn0search9|Independently derived the same spectrum; provides clear numerical examples and popularized the notation \(D_q\).|
|P. Grassberger & I. Procaccia, “**Measuring the strangeness of strange attractors**,” _Physica D_ 9 (1983) 189–208 citeturn0search3turn0search10|Introduced the now-standard correlation-integral algorithm for computing the \(q=2\) (correlation) dimension in data.|

## 3  Standard textbook expositions (for definitions, proofs, and context)  

| Reference | Scope |
|-----------|------|
|Kenneth Falconer, **_Fractal Geometry: Mathematical Foundations and Applications_** (Wiley, 1st ed. 1990; 3rd ed. 2014) citeturn0search4turn0search11|Rigorous treatment of Hausdorff, box-counting, information, and correlation dimensions, with full proofs.|
|Jens Feder, **_Fractals_** (Springer, 1988) citeturn0search5|Accessible physics-oriented overview; Chapter 9 walks through the Grassberger–Procaccia algorithm and the link to Rényi entropies.|

---

### How to weave them into your passage  

- **First sentence (defining fractal dimension)**: cite Falconer 1990 and Feder 1988 for general background.  
- **Equation for \(D_\alpha\)**: cite Rényi 1961 for the entropy definition and Hentschel & Procaccia 1983 or Grassberger 1983 for its application to attractors.  
- **Statements distinguishing \(D_0, D_1, D_2\)**: cite Grassberger & Procaccia 1983 (correlation dimension) and Falconer 1990 (box-counting and information dimensions).  

That combination will satisfy both historical accuracy and current community practice.

parts: let M be a matrix composed of vectors v_i, which are transported along the tangent flow of dx/dt = f(x). Write the time evolution of M and relate it to the conitnuity equation

thoughts.content: The user asks for the time evolution of a matrix \( M \) whose columns (or rows) consist of vectors \( v_i \) transported along the flow defined by \( dx/dt = f(x) \). I think the time evolution of \( M \) is \( M' = J(x) M \), where the Jacobian \( J \) is the partial derivative of \( f \) with respect to \( x \). From here, I’ll connect this to the continuity equation, yielding \( d/dt \log \det M = \nabla \cdot f \), aligning to the divergence of \( f \).

parts:
### 1.  Setting-up  

Let  

\[
\frac{d x}{d t}=f(x(t)),\qquad x(t)\in\mathbb R^{n},
\]

and let \(v_i(t)\) be \(n\) independent tangent vectors that are **dragged along the flow**, i.e. each \(v_i\) satisfies the variational (linearised) equation

\[
\frac{d v_i}{d t}=J(x(t))\,v_i,\qquad 
J(x)=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x)\in\mathbb R^{n\times n}.
\]

Collect the vectors as columns of the matrix

\[
M(t)=\bigl[v_1(t)\;\;v_2(t)\;\;\dots\;\;v_n(t)\bigr]\in\mathbb R^{n\times n}.
\]

---

### 2.  Time-evolution of the matrix \(M\)

Because the Jacobian \(J\) acts on each column in exactly the same way,

\[
\boxed{\;\displaystyle\frac{dM}{dt}=J(x(t))\,M(t).\;}
\]

This is the compact matrix form of the linear variational system.

---

### 3.  Determinant (volume element) evolution

Taking determinants and using \(\det(\mathrm e^{A})=\mathrm e^{\operatorname{tr}A}\),

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\ln\det M(t)=\operatorname{tr}J(x(t))=\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigl(x(t)\bigr).
\]

Hence

\[
\det M(t)=\det M(0)\,\exp\!\Bigl(\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigl(x(s)\bigr)\,ds\Bigr).
\]

So \(\det M\) measures how an infinitesimal material volume carried by the flow stretches or contracts.

---

### 4.  Link to the continuity (Liouville) equation

For a passive scalar density \(\rho(x,t)\) convected by the flow, the continuity equation is

\[
\frac{\partial\rho}{\partial t}+\nabla\!\cdot(\rho f)=0
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\frac{d}{dt}\rho\bigl(x(t),t\bigr)
=-\rho\,\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigl(x(t)\bigr).
\]

Thus along any trajectory

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\ln\rho\bigl(x(t),t\bigr)=-\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigl(x(t)\bigr)
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\rho(t)\,\det M(t)=\text{constant}.
\]

---

### 5.  Summary of the relationship  

| Quantity | Evolution along a trajectory |
|----------|-----------------------------|
| Basis matrix | \(\displaystyle\frac{dM}{dt}=J\,M\) |
| Volume element | \(\displaystyle\frac{d}{dt}\ln\det M=\nabla\!\cdot f\) |
| Density | \(\displaystyle\frac{d}{dt}\ln\rho=-\nabla\!\cdot f\) |

Because the divergence \(\nabla\!\cdot f\) appears with opposite signs in the last two lines, the product \(\rho\,\det M\) is invariant in time. This is Liouville’s theorem in continuum form: the flow maps phase-space volume and probability/ mass density in such a way that their product stays constant, guaranteeing conservation of total probability (or mass).
is \rho exactly proprtional to det M?

thoughts.content: The user is asking if \( \rho \) is exactly proportional to \( \text{det}(M) \). From earlier, \( \rho(t) \times \text{det}(M(t)) \) is constant along each trajectory, meaning \( \rho \) and \( \text{det}(M) \) are inversely proportional. Globally, though, \( \rho(x,t) = \frac{\rho(x_0, 0)}{\text{det}(M(t))} \), implying inverse proportionality. For incompressible flow (divergence = 0), \( \rho \) and \( \text{det}(M) \) are constant along the flow, with the Jacobian showing the relationship.

parts:
Not quite— the continuity equation tells us that **ρ is inversely proportional to det M, not directly proportional to it**.

---

### Flow-map viewpoint  

Let the flow generated by \(f\) be   
\[
\Phi_t:\;x_0\mapsto x(t)=\Phi_t(x_0),\qquad 
\partial_t\Phi_t=f\bigl(\Phi_t\bigr),\;\;\Phi_0=\mathrm{id}.
\]

Define the **deformation (Jacobian) matrix**

\[
M(t,x_0)=\frac{\partial\Phi_t}{\partial x_0}\in\mathbb R^{n\times n},
\qquad\det M(t,x_0)=J(t,x_0).
\]

---

### Continuity equation along characteristics  

For a passively advected density \(ρ\),

\[
\partial_tρ+\nabla\!\cdot(ρf)=0
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
ρ\bigl(\Phi_t(x_0),t\bigr)\,J(t,x_0)=ρ_0(x_0),
\]

where \(ρ_0(x_0)=ρ(x_0,0)\) is the **initial density**.

---

### Consequence  

\[
ρ\bigl(\Phi_t(x_0),t\bigr)=\frac{ρ_0(x_0)}{\det M(t,x_0)}.
\]

Hence, along each trajectory

* \(ρ\,\det M\) is conserved;
* \(ρ\) is **inversely** proportional to \(\det M\);  
  the constant of proportionality is the initial density at the starting point.

---

### Special cases  

* **Uniform initial density** \(ρ_0=\text{const}\):  
  \(ρ(t)=\text{const}\;\det M(t)^{-1}\). Now \(ρ\) is strictly \(1/\det M\) up to a global factor.

* **Incompressible flow** \((\nabla\!\cdot f=0)\):  
  \(\det M(t,x_0)=1\) for all \(t\), so \(ρ(t)=ρ_0(x_0)\); the density is frozen into the flow.

---

**Bottom line:** ρ is not exactly proportional to \(\det M\); it is proportional to its reciprocal, with the proportionality factor supplied by the initial density field.
if M has rank n-m where n is the state dim, then what is rho? is it like a m dimensiuonal dirac delta?

thoughts.summary: Interpreting reduced rank in matrix M
thoughts.content: The key here is that if matrix M has rank n - m, the flow only spans an n - m-dimensional subspace. So the volume associated with the flow degenerates into a lower-dimensional manifold. This means the Jacobian determinant is zero since the rank is less than n. For the continuity equation, I can say that rho times the determinant of M remains constant, equal to the product of the initial density and the initial determinant.

thoughts.summary: Understanding the behavior of density with reduced rank
thoughts.content: If the determinant of M is zero, density (rho) might diverge to infinity depending on how the flow map degenerates. If flow collapses, the density turns into a generalized distribution, supported on a lower-dimensional manifold. In the case of reduced rank, rho behaves like a Dirac delta function in the collapsed directions, resulting in a distribution supported on an (n-m)-dimensional manifold. Essentially, rho becomes a singular measure, which is not a smooth function, but a combination of delta distributions and a smooth density in the remaining directions.

parts:
Yes—once the flow has collapsed m independent directions (so the deformation matrix
\(M(t,x_0)\) has rank \(n-m\)) the **mass/­probability density in the full \(n\)-dimensional
space ceases to be an ordinary function**.  
Instead it becomes a *singular measure* that is concentrated on the
\((n-m)\)-dimensional sheet traced out by the surviving directions.  The most economical
way to write it is exactly the way you suggested:

\[
\rho(t,x)=\sigma(\xi,t)\,\delta^{(m)}(\eta),
\]

* \(\xi\in\mathbb R^{\,n-m}\) are coordinates **tangent** to the sheet
  \(\mathcal S_t=\Phi_t(\mathcal S_0)\);
* \(\eta\in\mathbb R^{\,m}\) are **normal** coordinates measuring distance away from
  \(\mathcal S_t\);
* \(\delta^{(m)}\) is the \(m\)-dimensional Dirac delta supported on \(\eta=0\);
* \(\sigma(\xi,t)\) is an ordinary (absolutely continuous) density on
  \(\mathcal S_t\).\*

---

### How it emerges from the continuity equation  

1. **Push-forward of the initial measure.**  
   Starting from a regular density \(\rho_0(x_0)\,d^nx_0\), the flow map
   \(\Phi_t:x_0\mapsto x\) pushes this \(n\)-form forward.  
   When \(\operatorname{rank}M(t,x_0)=n-m\) the
   full Jacobian determinant is zero, so the push-forward no longer defines an
   \(n\)-form; it defines an \((n-m)\)-form on the immersed submanifold \(\mathcal S_t\).

2. **Surface density.**  
   Choose local coordinates \((\xi,\eta)\) with \(\eta=0\) on \(\mathcal S_t\).
   Then mass conservation gives

   \[
   \sigma(\xi,t)\,\bigl|M_\parallel(t,x_0)\bigr|\,d^{\,n-m}\xi
   =\rho_0(x_0)\,d^nx_0,
   \]

   where \(M_\parallel\) is the non-degenerate \((n-m)\times(n-m)\) block of \(M\)
   acting on the tangent directions.  Hence

   \[
   \sigma(\xi,t)=\frac{\rho_0(x_0)}{\det M_\parallel(t,x_0)}.
   \]

   This is the same inverse-determinant law as before, but now applied only to the
   directions that survive.

3. **Distribution in the ambient space.**  
   Writing the pushed-forward measure back in the full space requires a Dirac delta in
   the collapsed directions, producing the representation
   \(\rho=\sigma\,\delta^{(m)}(\eta)\).

---

### Intuitively  

* **Before collapse** \(\det M>0\) and \(\rho\) is smooth.  
* **During collapse** \(\det M\downarrow0\) and \(\rho\sim(\det M)^{-1}\) blows up.  
* **After collapse** the blow-up is re-interpreted as a genuine concentration of mass
  on a lower-dimensional set, encoded by Dirac deltas.

This picture is common in Hamiltonian systems with integral invariants, shock
formation in conservation laws, and aggregation systems where mass collects on
filaments or sheets.

---

\*If \(m>1\) there is some freedom in how one chooses the factorisation
\(\sigma\,\delta^{(m)}\); only the product is canonical.
what's the formula for rank?

thoughts.content: The user's question about the formula for rank is a bit unclear. They were discussing a matrix, M, composed of vectors that evolve in a certain way. When they ask for "the formula for rank," I'm considering different possibilities. It could refer to the rank definition (linearly independent rows/columns, column space dimension, nonzero singular values, or row-echelon form). I could also include the "rank-nullity" theorem, where the rank equals the total number of columns minus the nullity.

parts:
Below are the most common, equivalent “formulas’’ for the rank of a matrix \(A\in\mathbb R^{m\times n}\).  Pick whichever is most convenient for the situation:

| Viewpoint | Formula / Criterion |
|-----------|--------------------|
| **Linear-algebraic definition** | \(\displaystyle \operatorname{rank}A = \dim\bigl(\text{Im}\,A\bigr)=\dim\bigl(\text{Col}(A)\bigr)\). |
| **Row version** | \(\displaystyle \operatorname{rank}A = \dim\bigl(\text{Row}(A)\bigr)\). |
| **Rank–nullity theorem** | \(\displaystyle \operatorname{rank}A = n-\dim\bigl(\ker A\bigr)\). |
| **Determinantal (minor) criterion** | \(\displaystyle \operatorname{rank}A = \max\{k\;|\;\exists\;k\times k\text{ sub-determinant}\neq0\}\). |
| **RREF / Gaussian elimination** | \(\displaystyle \operatorname{rank}A = \text{number of pivot (leading-1) columns in the reduced row-echelon form of }A\). |
| **Singular values** | \(\displaystyle \operatorname{rank}A = \#\{\sigma_i>0\}\) where \(\sigma_i\) are the singular values from \(A=U\Sigma V^{\!\top}\). |

---

### In your specific setting  

For the deformation matrix \(M(t,x_0)=\partial\Phi_t/\partial x_0\):

* If at some \((t,x_0)\) you find  
  \[
    \operatorname{rank}M(t,x_0)=n-m,
  \]
  then exactly \(m\) singular values (and \(m\) principal minors of size \(n\)) have vanished, so \(m\) independent directions have collapsed and the image of \(M\) is an \((n-m)\)-dimensional subspace tangent to the advected sheet.  

Any of the formulas above can be used to verify that rank; e.g. detecting \(m\) zero singular values or finding that every \((n-m+1)\!\times\!(n-m+1)\) determinant vanishes while at least one \((n-m)\!\times\!(n-m)\) determinant remains non-zero.
is there an agreed upon way to measure rank as a real number for a matrix?

### 1.  Why the usual rank is always an integer
The algebraic rank of a matrix \(A\in\mathbb R^{m\times n}\),

\[
\operatorname{rank}A=\#\{\,\sigma_i>0\,\},
\]

counts the non-zero singular values \(\sigma_i\).  Because you either keep or lose a dimension, the exact rank can only be an integer.

### 2.  “Real-valued” relaxations used in practice
Numerical linear-algebra and information theory often need a **continuous surrogate** for rank—one that

* varies smoothly when the singular values are perturbed,  
* reflects how *close* the matrix is to being low rank, and  
* reduces to the integer rank in the ideal noise-free case.

There is no single, universally accepted choice, but the following four definitions appear repeatedly in the literature:

| Name | Definition (in terms of singular values \(\sigma_1\ge\ldots\ge\sigma_r>0\)) | Range | Key property |
|------|---------------------------------------------|-------|--------------|
| **Stable rank** | \(\displaystyle r_{\text{st}}(A)=\frac{\|A\|_F^{\,2}}{\|A\|_2^{\,2}}=\frac{\sum_{i}\sigma_i^{2}}{\sigma_1^{2}}\) | \((0,\;\operatorname{rank}A]\) | Unitarily invariant and 1-Lipschitz; widely used in randomized linear algebra. |
| **Effective (ε-numerical) rank** | \(\displaystyle r_\varepsilon(A)=\#\bigl\{i:\sigma_i>\varepsilon\,\sigma_1\bigr\}\) for a user-chosen tolerance \(\varepsilon\in(0,1)\) | \(\{0,1,\ldots,\operatorname{rank}A\}\) | Simple thresholding; depends on ε. MATLAB’s `rank` uses this idea. |
| **Entropy (Shannon) rank** | \(\displaystyle r_{\text{ent}}(A)=\exp\Bigl(-\sum_{i}p_i\log p_i\Bigr),\quad p_i=\sigma_i^{2}\Big/\sum_j\sigma_j^{2}\) | \((1,\;\operatorname{rank}A]\) | Equals the exponentiated entropy of the normalized energy spectrum; smooth and parameter-free. |
| **Nuclear-over-spectral ratio** | \(\displaystyle r_{\text{spec}}(A)=\frac{\|A\|_*}{\|A\|_2}=\frac{\sum_i\sigma_i}{\sigma_1}\) | \([1,\;\operatorname{rank}A]\) | Convex surrogate often used in convex relaxations of rank minimisation. |

All four coincide with the algebraic rank when the non-zero singular values are equal; they diverge only when the spectrum is spread out.

### 3.  Choosing one in practice
* **Data compression / PCA:** entropy rank measures how uniformly the variance is distributed—handy for deciding intrinsic dimensionality.
* **Randomised matrix approximation & sketching:** stable rank has tight tail bounds and clean concentration results.
* **Engineering tolerances:** ε-numerical rank is attractive when you can specify “anything below 10⁻¹² of the max singular value is noise.”
* **Optimisation problems:** nuclear-over-spectral ratio (or directly the nuclear norm) provides a convex objective.

### 4.  Bottom line
There is *no* single canonical “real-valued rank.”  Instead you pick a smooth functional of the singular values that fits your application’s notion of “almost low rank.”  Among practitioners the **stable rank** and the **entropy (effective) rank** are the most frequently cited because they are parameter-free and scale gracefully with noise.
Can you take a nonlinear ODE and approximate it with a high dimensional linear ODE

Yes, you *can* approximate a nonlinear ODE with a high-dimensional linear ODE using **embedding methods** or **lifting techniques**. The idea is to represent nonlinear dynamics in a larger space where the evolution becomes (approximately) linear.

Here are the most prominent frameworks:

---

### 1. **Koopman Operator Theory**
- A nonlinear system:
  \[
  \frac{d\mathbf{x}}{dt} = \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x})
  \]
  can be lifted to a higher-dimensional function space where observables \( g(\mathbf{x}) \) evolve linearly:
  \[
  \frac{d}{dt} g(\mathbf{x}(t)) = \mathcal{K} g(\mathbf{x}(t))
  \]
  Here \( \mathcal{K} \) is the **Koopman operator**, an (infinite-dimensional) linear operator acting on observables.

- In practice, you approximate this with a **finite-dimensional truncation**:
  \[
  \frac{d\mathbf{z}}{dt} = A \mathbf{z}
  \]
  where \( \mathbf{z} \in \mathbb{R}^N \) is a lifted representation (e.g., polynomials, radial basis functions of \( \mathbf{x} \)).

---

### 2. **Carleman Linearization**
- Expand the nonlinear terms (e.g. products like \( x^2, xy \)) into an augmented state vector:
  \[
  \frac{d\mathbf{z}}{dt} = A \mathbf{z}
  \]
  where \( \mathbf{z} = [x, y, x^2, xy, y^2, \dots] \)

- Truncate at some polynomial degree to yield a finite-dimensional approximation. The result is a linear ODE that approximates the original nonlinear one near the expansion point.

---

### 3. **Neural or Dictionary-based Lifting**
- Use a neural network or fixed basis (e.g. Fourier modes, wavelets) to transform \( \mathbf{x} \mapsto \phi(\mathbf{x}) \in \mathbb{R}^N \)
- Then fit a linear model:
  \[
  \frac{d}{dt} \phi(\mathbf{x}) \approx A \phi(\mathbf{x})
  \]
- This is a data-driven approximation of Koopman dynamics.

---

### Limitations
- The approximation is only valid **locally** or **on a suitable invariant set** (e.g. attractor).
- Truncation introduces errors; the linear system won't capture all nonlinear behaviors (e.g. bifurcations) globally.
- Some systems (e.g., chaotic ones) are poorly approximated by low-dimensional linear lifts.

---

Would you like a worked example (e.g., Van der Pol oscillator via Carleman linearization)?
In the limit as dim goes to infinity, you get a PDE. What is the PDE?

Excellent question.

In the **Carleman linearization** or **Koopman operator** setting, when the dimension of the lifted linear system tends to infinity, the limiting object is an **infinite-dimensional linear PDE**. The specific form of the PDE depends on the approach. Here are the two key cases:

---

### 1. **Koopman Operator PDE**

Let’s consider a nonlinear ODE:
\[
\frac{d\mathbf{x}}{dt} = \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}), \quad \mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n
\]

Let \( g(\mathbf{x}) \) be a scalar observable (i.e., a function of the state). The **Koopman PDE** governing its evolution is:
\[
\frac{\partial g}{\partial t} = \mathcal{K} g := \nabla g(\mathbf{x}) \cdot \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x})
\]

This is a **first-order linear PDE** in the function space of observables \( g \). The operator \( \mathcal{K} \) is the **Koopman generator**, and it acts as a linear differential operator, even though the underlying ODE is nonlinear.

So the PDE is:
\[
\frac{\partial g(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t} = \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}) \cdot \nabla g(\mathbf{x}, t)
\]

This governs the evolution of any scalar observable of the system. It can be seen as a **transport equation** in the space of observables.

---

### 2. **Carleman Linearization Limit**

Suppose you expand \( \mathbf{x}(t) \) in a basis of monomials \( x^k \), and write:
\[
\frac{d}{dt} z_k(t) = \sum_j A_{kj} z_j(t)
\]

As you take the degree of monomials to infinity, you get an **infinite system of ODEs** that can be interpreted as a PDE for a function \( z(x,t) \), defined over the infinite-dimensional function space of monomials (e.g., power series in \( x \)). The form of this PDE depends heavily on the structure of \( \mathbf{f} \), but for analytic vector fields \( \mathbf{f} \), it resembles a **linear PDE in the function space of analytic functions**.

However, this interpretation is less standardized than the Koopman one and typically appears in the context of formal series methods.

---

### Summary

The canonical answer is:

\[
\frac{\partial g(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t} = \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}) \cdot \nabla g(\mathbf{x}, t)
\]

This is the **Koopman evolution PDE**. It is linear in \( g \), but infinite-dimensional due to the space of all observables.

Would you like to see how this emerges from a concrete nonlinear ODE example?
What is g for the Lorenz system?

thoughts.content: The user is asking about "g" for the Lorenz system, possibly looking for an explicit expression for an observable function within the Koopman operator's PDE. Their question on "g" refers to a scalar observable, which can be any function of the state, like coordinates (x, y, z) or polynomials. The PDE describes how any such function evolves over time, considering the system’s vector field. For example, if \(g(x, y, z, t) = x\), the corresponding PDE is \(\partial g/\partial t = \sigma(y - x)\).

parts: What is g for the Lorenz system?

For the Lorenz system

\[
\dot x = \sigma\,(y-x),\qquad 
\dot y = x(\rho-z)-y,\qquad
\dot z = xy-\beta z ,
\]

the **Koopman-generator transport equation** for any scalar observable  
\(g:\math

thoughts.content: The user is asking about "g" for the Lorenz system, which seems related to a previous question about a scalar observable and its PDE in the infinite dimension limit. "g" could refer to any observables like coordinates or functions expanded in basis under the Koopman operator. I'm wondering if they want the explicit form of "g" or the solution to the PDE. The question may also relate to the generator or the expression of the operator itself. Maybe I should ask for clarification to be sure!

parts:
For the Lorenz equations  

\[
\dot x = \sigma (y-x),\qquad
\dot y = x(\rho-z)-y,\qquad
\dot z = xy-\beta z ,
\]

the **Koopman‐generator PDE** for any scalar observable \(g=g(x,y,z,t)\) is obtained by inserting the vector field  
\(\mathbf f=(\sigma(y-x),\,x(\rho-z)-y,\,xy-\beta z)\) into  

\[
\partial_t g \;=\; \mathbf f\!\cdot\!\nabla g .
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_t g \;=\;
\sigma (y-x)\,\partial_x g
\;+\;
\bigl[x(\rho-z)-y\bigr]\,\partial_y g
\;+\;
\bigl[xy-\beta z\bigr]\,\partial_z g .
\;}
\tag{1}
\]

---

### What “\(g\)” can be

* **Arbitrary smooth observable.**  
  Any \(C^{1}\) (usually \(C^{\infty}\) or analytic) scalar function of \((x,y,z)\). For example  
  * \(g_1(x,y,z)=x\) gives \(\partial_t x = \sigma(y-x)\),  
  * \(g_2(x,y,z)=y\) gives \(\partial_t y = x(\rho-z)-y\),  
  * \(g_3(x,y,z)=z\) gives \(\partial_t z = xy-\beta z\).  
  Each simply recovers a component of the ODE when inserted into (1).

* **Polynomial or Fourier dictionary for finite truncations.**  
  Choosing all monomials up to degree \(p\) (e.g.\ \(1,x,y,z,x^2,xy,\dots\)) yields the familiar Carleman/EDMD finite‐dimensional lift. Equation (1) applied to that dictionary produces a large **linear** ODE \(\dot{\mathbf z}=A\mathbf z\) whose size grows rapidly with \(p\).

* **Data-driven / neural observables.**  
  If you learn a feature map \(\phi:\mathbb R^{3}\!\to\!\mathbb R^{N}\) from data, each component \(\phi_i\) is a legitimate \(g\) satisfying (1); together they give a finite Galerkin projection of the Koopman PDE.

---

### Solution along characteristics

Because (1) is a first-order linear transport equation, its solution is obtained by following the Lorenz flow \(\Phi^{t}\):

\[
g(x,y,z,t)=g_0\!\bigl(\Phi^{-t}(x,y,z)\bigr),
\]

where \(g_0(x,y,z)=g(x,y,z,0)\) is the “initial condition” in observable space.  
In other words, \(g\) is constant along trajectories of the Lorenz system pulled back in time.

---

**Bottom line:** there is no unique “\(g\)” for the Lorenz system; equation (1) tells you how *any* smooth scalar observable must evolve. Choosing a family of such observables (monomials, Fourier modes, neural features, …) and truncating gives the high-dimensional linear ODE that approximates the nonlinear Lorenz dynamics.

thoughts.summary: Defining g for the Lorenz system
thoughts.content: g in the Lorenz system is a scalar function or observable defined on the state space (x, y, z). It represents a quantity whose evolution is described by the Koopman partial differential equation (PDE). While g can be any smooth function of the state variables, its precise form depends on the context. For the Lorenz system, g could be something like x, y, or z, but it can be other smoothly varying functions as well.

parts:
For the Lorenz system the state vector is  
\[
\mathbf{x}=(x,y,z)^{\!\top}\in\mathbb R^{3},\qquad  
\dot x=\sigma (y-x),\quad  
\dot y=x(\rho-z)-y,\quad  
\dot z=xy-\beta z .
\]

---

### Koopman viewpoint  

Pick **any** sufficiently smooth scalar observable  

\[
g:\mathbb R^{3}\longrightarrow\mathbb R,\qquad 
g=g(x,y,z).
\]

The generator of the Lorenz flow is the first-order differential operator  

\[
\mathcal K
 \;=\;
\sigma(y-x)\,\partial_x
\;+\;
\bigl(x(\rho-z)-y\bigr)\,\partial_y
\;+\;
\bigl(xy-\beta z\bigr)\,\partial_z .
\]

Hence **every** such observable evolves according to the linear PDE

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{\partial g}{\partial t}
=\mathcal K g
=\sigma(y-x)\frac{\partial g}{\partial x}
+\bigl(x(\rho-z)-y\bigr)\frac{\partial g}{\partial y}
+\bigl(xy-\beta z\bigr)\frac{\partial g}{\partial z}\;}
\tag{1}
\]

---

### What “\(g\)” can be

- **Coordinate observables:** \(g_1=x,\;g_2=y,\;g_3=z.\)  
  Equation (1) reproduces the original Lorenz ODEs when applied to each.

- **Monomials / polynomial dictionary:** To build a Carleman or finite Koopman approximation one typically lifts with  
  \[
  g_{ijk}(x,y,z)=x^{\,i}y^{\,j}z^{\,k},\qquad i+j+k\le m,
  \]
  for some truncation order \(m\).  Acting with \(\mathcal K\) on this dictionary produces a (very large) closed linear system whose dimension grows combinatorially with \(m\).

- **Fourier, radial basis, or neural-network features:** Any complete set of smooth functions can serve, provided it is rich enough to approximate the observables of interest and is closed under \(\mathcal K\) after truncation.

So the answer is: **“\(g\)” is an arbitrary smooth scalar observable on \(\mathbb R^{3}\); its evolution is dictated by the linear, infinite-dimensional PDE (1).**  In practice you choose a concrete family of \(g\)’s (monomials, Fourier modes, learned features, …) to obtain a high-dimensional but finite linear surrogate for the Lorenz dynamics.
Can you write the continuity / liouville equation with a koopman operator

thoughts.content: The user wants a connection between the continuity/Liouville equation and the Koopman operator, including the relevant derivation. The continuity equation can be written as ∂ρ/∂t + ∇·(fρ) = 0. I'll note that the Koopman operator acts on observables, and their evolution is given as ∂g/∂t = f·∇g. The Liouville operator is the adjoint of the Koopman generator. Using the inner product, I'll show that the Liouville equation arises, with the formal proof about adjointness leading to ∂ρ/∂t = -∇·(fρ).

parts:
Let  

\[
\dot{\mathbf{x}} = \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}), \qquad 
\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb R^{n}
\tag{1}
\]

be a \(C^{1}\) flow and let  

* **Koopman generator** acting on smooth observables  
  \(g:\mathbb R^{n}\!\to\!\mathbb R\)

  \[
  \mathcal K g := \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x})\!\cdot\!\nabla g(\mathbf{x}),
  \tag{2}
  \]

  so that \( \partial_t g = \mathcal K g\).

* **Densities** \( \rho(\mathbf{x},t)\ge 0,\; \int\rho\,d\mathbf{x}=1\).

---

### Duality

Equip \(L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\) with the standard inner product  
\(\langle g,h\rangle = \int g\,h\,d\mathbf{x}\).  
For all sufficiently smooth \(g,\rho\),

\[
\langle \mathcal K g,\rho\rangle
=\int (\mathbf{f}\!\cdot\!\nabla g)\,\rho\,d\mathbf{x}
=-\int g\,\nabla\!\cdot(\mathbf{f}\rho)\,d\mathbf{x}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\mathcal K^{*}\rho=-\,\nabla\!\cdot(\mathbf{f}\rho),
\tag{3}
\]

where the boundary term vanishes if either \(\rho\) or \(g\) has compact support or \(\rho\to 0\) fast enough at infinity.  
Thus **\(\mathcal K^{*}\)**, the adjoint of the Koopman generator, is the **Liouville (Perron–Frobenius) generator**.

---

### Continuity / Liouville equation in Koopman form

\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_t \rho = \mathcal K^{*}\rho
          = -\,\nabla\!\cdot(\mathbf{f}\rho)\;}
\tag{4}
\]

Equation (4) is the continuity (Liouville) equation expressing conservation of probability under the deterministic flow (1).  
Combining (2) and (4):

* **Observable evolution:** \(\partial_t g = \mathcal K g\)
* **Density evolution:** \(\partial_t \rho = \mathcal K^{*}\rho\)

and for any time-dependent expectation,

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\langle g,\rho\rangle
=\langle \mathcal K g,\rho\rangle
=\langle g,\mathcal K^{*}\rho\rangle,
\]

so the coupled pair \((\mathcal K,\mathcal K^{*})\) provides a linear, infinite-dimensional representation of the nonlinear ODE, acting on observables and densities respectively.
but can't you also write \frac{d}{dt}\rho = -\mathcal{K} \rho?

thoughts.summary: Clarifying Koopman operator on density evolution
thoughts.content: The user is suggesting writing \( \frac{d}{dt} \rho = -\mathcal{K} \rho \), possibly thinking of the Koopman operator acting on density with a negative sign. Generally, the Koopman operator acts on observables, and its adjoint acts on density. The negative sign appears only after integration by parts, assuming a divergence-free flow. If the flow is incompressible, the Liouville equation becomes \( \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} = -\nabla \cdot (f \rho) \). So, we can show that the negative sign comes from the integration process.

parts: but can't you also write \partial_t \rho = - \nabla \cdot f \rho -\mathcal{K} \rho?

thoughts.content: The user asks if it's valid to rewrite the equation ∂_t ρ = -∇·(f ρ) as ∂_t ρ = -∇·f ρ - Kρ, with K being the Koopman generator. The original equation involves a divergence term that depends on ∇·f and f·∇ρ. K acts on observables, not directly on densities, so the decomposition needs careful consideration. Based on this, it seems correct to rewrite it as ∂_t ρ = - K ρ - ρ ∇·f.

parts:
Yes—you can split the single divergence term into two pieces, but you must place the parentheses correctly so it’s clear which quantity each operator acts on.

Starting from the continuity / Liouville form  

\[
\partial_t \rho \;=\; -\,\nabla\!\cdot\bigl(\mathbf{f}\,\rho\bigr),
\]

apply the product rule:

\[
-\nabla\!\cdot\bigl(\mathbf{f}\,\rho\bigr)
\,=\;
-\bigl(\mathbf{f}\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho\bigr)\;-\;\rho\,\bigl(\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf{f}\bigr).
\]

Recognising that the Koopman generator acts on any scalar function \(h(\mathbf{x})\) by  

\[
\mathcal K h \;=\; \mathbf{f}\!\cdot\!\nabla h,
\]

we have  

\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_t \rho
\;=\;
-\rho\,(\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf{f})
\;-\;
\mathcal K \rho.
\;}
\]

So the form you suggested is correct **provided it’s read as**  

\[
-\bigl(\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf{f}\bigr)\,\rho\;-\;\mathcal K\rho,
\]

not as \(-\nabla\!\cdot\bigl(\mathbf{f}\,\rho\bigr)-\mathcal K\rho\) (which would double-count the transport term).

---

**Special case: incompressible (divergence-free) flow**  
If \(\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf{f}=0\), then the first term disappears and the Liouville equation reduces to

\[
\partial_t \rho = -\,\mathcal K \rho,
\]

showing that the density is transported purely by the Koopman advection operator.
how do you interpret this/

Think of a large cloud of passive tracer particles moving under the vector field \(\mathbf f(\mathbf x)\).

---

### Two distinct mechanisms change the Eulerian density \(\rho(\mathbf x,t)\)

| term in \(\displaystyle \partial_t\rho =-\rho\,(\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf f)\;-\;\mathcal K\rho\) | physical meaning | geometric meaning |
|---|---|---|
| \(-\,\rho\,(\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf f)\) | **Local dilution or compression**.  Where \(\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf f<0\) the flow squashes phase-space volume, concentrating particles; where \(\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf f>0\) it stretches volume, thinning the cloud. | The Jacobian determinant of the flow map changes volumes at rate \(\exp\bigl(\int -\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf f\,dt\bigr)\).  This term alone would act like a “source/sink” distributed in space. |
| \(-\,\mathcal K\rho=-\,\mathbf f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho\) | **Pure advection**.  Tracer mass is transported along trajectories without changing the amount inside each co-moving fluid element. | Each point of the cloud slides along the streamline defined by \(\mathbf f\).  In a Lagrangian frame this term vanishes—only the divergence term is felt. |

---

### Special cases  

* **Divergence-free (\(\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf f=0\))**  
  Volume is preserved (Hamiltonian or incompressible flow).  The density just rides the flow: \(\partial_t\rho=-\mathcal K\rho\).

* **Purely dissipative (\(\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf f<0\) everywhere)**  
  Volumes contract exponentially toward lower-dimensional attractors.  Even if \(\rho\) is uniform initially, the compression term creates strong inhomogeneities.

---

### Operator-theoretic view  

* \(\mathcal K\) is the **Koopman generator** acting on functions (observables).  
* Its adjoint \(\mathcal K^{*}\) acts on densities: \(\partial_t\rho=\mathcal K^{*}\rho\).  
* Writing \(\mathcal K^{*}\) as \(-\rho\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf f-\mathcal K\) separates the **divergence (Jacobian) part** from the **transport part**, clarifying how phase-space measure evolves.

---

So the split form tells you:  

1. **Where** the flow expands or contracts space (\(-\rho\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf f\)).  
2. **How** the density is carried along trajectories (\(-\mathcal K\rho\)).  

Together they fully encode conservation of probability under any deterministic ODE flow.
